title: End-to-End Chart Summarization via Visual Chain-of-Thought in Vision-Language Models
author: Raymond Choi (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro), Frank Burns (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro), Chase Lawrence (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro), ... , Alexander Yang (Federal University of Rio de Janeiro)
relevance_why: The proposed end-to-end approach for visual reasoning and summarization could inspire similar methodologies for generating audio descriptions or annotations from visual or textual prompts in sound-related tasks.
background: Automated chart summarization involves creating text descriptions from chart images, which can help users efficiently interpret complex data.
contribution: This paper introduces the End-to-End Visual Chain-of-Thought method to solve challenges in chart summarization, achieving significant improvements in automated evaluation metrics.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often relied on separate data extraction modules, leading to challenges in accuracy and coherence in generated summaries.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by directly integrating visual reasoning into the summarization process without requiring pre-processing, enhancing both summary quality and reasoning accuracy.

key_innovation: Utilizes a visual Chain-of-Thought mechanism within Large Vision-Language Models to guide the process of real-time visual analysis and summary generation.
real_world_impact: Improving automated summarization of charts can enhance data accessibility for users, including those with visual impairments, ultimately aiding in decision-making across various sectors.

new_terms.Chain-of-Thought: **Chain-of-Thought** is a reasoning approach that guides the model through a series of steps to arrive at the final conclusion or output, mimicking human reasoning.
